title: 112_hr2465
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Federal Workers' Compensation Modernization and Improvement Act". Physician assistants and advanced practice nurses are included in the Act. The Act, known as the "Federal Workers' Compensation Modernization and Improvement Act," includes provisions for medical services. These services may now encompass treatment by physician assistants or advanced practice nurses within their defined scope of practice as per State law and regulations set by the Secretary of Labor. (c) Certification of Traumatic Injury.--Section 8121(6) of title 5, United States Code, is amended to allow physician assistants or advanced practice nurses, like nurse practitioners, to certify traumatic injuries and related disabilities during the continuation of pay period covered by section 8118, in accordance with regulations set by the Secretary of Labor. SEC. 3. COVERING TERRORISM INJURIES. Amends Section 8102(b) of title 5, United States Code to include coverage for injuries from terrorist attacks. SEC. 4. DISFIGUREMENT. Section 8107(c)(21) of title 5, United States Code now allows for compensation up to $50,000 for serious disfigurement of the face, head, or neck resulting from an injury occurring within 3 years prior to the enactment of the Federal Workers' Compensation Modernization and Improvement Act. This compensation is in addition to any other benefits and will be adjusted annually based on the cost of living. The compensation for serious disfigurement under Section 8107(c)(21) of title 5, United States Code can now be up to $50,000 and will be adjusted annually based on the cost of living. SEC. 5. SOCIAL SECURITY EARNINGS INFORMATION.

Section 8116 of title 5, United States Code, amended to allow the Secretary of Labor to require consent for release of Social Security earnings information for benefits under this subchapter.

SEC. 6. CONTINUATION OF PAY IN A ZONE OF ARMED CONFLICT. Section 8118 of title 5, United States Code is amended to authorize the continuation of pay for employees who have filed a claim for wage loss due to traumatic injury in a zone of armed conflict. Employees can file a claim for wage loss benefits within 45 days of leaving a zone of armed conflict or returning to the United States. Continuation of pay can last up to 135 days without interruption, unless contested by the Secretary of Labor. The determination of zones of armed conflict is made by the Secretary of Labor in consultation with the Secretary of State and the Secretary of Defense. The Armed Forces of the United States can be involved in hostilities in a country or area if civil insurrection, civil war, terrorism, or wartime conditions threaten harm to US civilian employees. The President can designate a combat zone under specific circumstances, and other relevant conditions may also apply. SEC. 7. Subrogation of continuation of pay. Amends Section 8131 of title 5, United States Code to include "continuation of pay or" before "compensation" in subsections (a) and (c). Also amends Section 8132 to include "continuation of pay or" before "compensation" in multiple instances and adjust language regarding recovery from a third person. SEC. 8. Funeral expenses. SEC. 8. FUNERAL EXPENSES. Amends Section 8134 of title 5, United States Code to provide for the payment of funeral and burial expenses up to $6,000 for deaths resulting from duty-related injuries. Adjustments to the maximum compensation for burial expenses will be made annually. SEC. 9. EMPLOYEES' COMPENSATION FUND. Amends Section 8147 of title 5, United States Code to include administrative expenses and provide estimates for funds needed to administer the subchapter. SEC. 10. CONFORMING AMENDMENT. Amends Section 8101(1)(D) to include individuals injured before March 3, 1979. SEC. 11. EFFECTIVE DATE. SEC. 11. EFFECTIVE DATE. This Act and its amendments will take effect 60 days after enactment.
